title: Worst Remake Ever
review: If you haven't seen this movie, don't waste your time with it. It was absolutely nothing like the original movie. Sure, there were some comedic sections in it, but because of the lack of dramatic elements, the death of Chris Rock's character was unbearable and came out of nowhere. Not to mention Courtney Cox's character was an absolute bitch, and the part with the transvestite cheerleaders was flat-out wrong. If any remake was about the worst thing to hit theaters, it was this one, not to mention I was not impressed with Sandler at all.In short, don't see this movie. If you have, and you loved it, go rent the original, and you'll see what I'm talking about.

title: A Well-Rounded Performance by Everyone
review: When I first heard of 'Little Miss Sunshine', I thought it was an interesting idea for a movie. Its concept was new, fresh, and had never been done before. But it wasn't the endearing story that I was really impressed with. What I was really impressed by was the performance by each of the talented actors.'Little Miss Sunshine' carries a cast of pretty colorful characters, including Alan Arkin as a sex-obsessed heroin addict for a grandfather, and Steve Carell as a a homosexual man, who, after losing the man he loves, as well as his title as #1 scholar in America, attempts suicide. The cast also includes Paul Dano as a disturbed teenager who has taken a vow of silence until he reaches his goal to be an Air Force pilot, Greg Kinnear as a motivational speaker for his '9 Steps to Becoming a Winner', Toni Collette as a mom who tries to be optimistic even when she knows things are falling apart, and, of course, we can't forget about Abigail Breslin's performance as Olive, an excited 7 year-old who is determined to win the Little Miss Sunshine Pageant in Redondo Beach, CA. These were very different roles for all of the actors, and showed their incredible range of talent. This especially goes for Steve Carell, who spends most of his time being the boss of 'The Office', where it doesn't require a whole lot of acting. Abigail Breslin definitely applies here, too. She's definitely not that little girl from 'Raising Helen' anymore, and her Academy Award nomination was well deserved.'Little Miss Sunshine' won the 2007 Oscar for Best Original Screenplay, and Alan Arkin received an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor. It has received 28 more wins and 34 more nominations for various awards. 'Little Miss Sunshine' is a treat and I would recommend it for anyone over the age of 13.

title: The Logic of 'Oz'
review: How many times have you heard the words 'Toto, I don't think we're in Kansas anymore' in your lifetime? Afterall it's one of the most cherished film quotes in the history of film. The line, although simple, is powerful in itself, and introduces the turn of the film.Let's start from the beginning, and break it down...Exposition: Dorothy is a girl from Kansas who dreams of more than the boring farm life she is used to.Rising Action: One day, a tornado comes along and transports Dorothy and her dog, Toto, to the magical land of Oz, which resides over the rainbow. Upon her arrival, Dorothy meets Glinda, the Good Witch of the North, who directs Dorothy to the powerful, but mysterious, Wizard of Oz. Soon, Dorothy sets out on a quest down the Yellow-Brick Road, to the Emerald City. Along the way, she has a run-in with the Wicked Witch of the West, who is mad at Dorothy for dropping a house on her sister and taking the ruby slippers that the sister was wearing. Dorothy also meets the Scarecrow, who desperately wants a brain, the Tin Man, who desperately wants a heart, and the Cowardly Lion, who is in desperate need of courage. They all join together to go to the Emerald City, where the Wizard lives. When they reach the city, and meet the Wizard, he tells them to kill the Wicked Witch of the West, and retrieve her broomstick. On the way to the castle, Dorothy and Toto are taken by the witch's flying monkeys and held captive in the castle. Toto escapes and finds the others. He leads the Scarecrow, Tin Man, and Cowardly Lion to the castle to save Dorothy.Climax: The Wicked Witch of the West sets the Scarecrow on fire, and, in attempt to extinguish the flames, Dorothy throws a bucket of water upon the Wicked Witch and melts her. Triumphed, the four friends set out back to the Emerald City to claim their gifts.Falling Action: Dorothy and her friends arrive at the Emerald City only to find that the Wizard is a big fake with no power whatsoever. He does, however, help the Scarecrow, the Tin Man, and the Cowardly Lion realize that they've had what they've been looking for all along. That just leaves Dorothy. The Wizard decides to take Dorothy back to Kansas himself in his balloon. But the balloon departs before Dorothy can climb in, and she is back to square one. Almost right after, Glinda arrives and tells Dorothy that she has always had the power to go home. All she has to do, Glinda says, is to click her heels three times, and say 'There's No Place Like Home!'Resolution: Dorothy is home, with her family and friends, where she plans to stay for a long time.So, you see, if you think about it, this movie is very logical, and if you haven't already, make sure to see this movie as soon as possible. You'll find that this film is the definition of a classic.
